Many people are confused by "my mother is a fish."  I believe it's an idea that when reading Faulkner to look for answers from the author.  Although the complete answer is a Faulkner sentence or two of considerable length, I'll just butcher it somewhat mercilessly.  You may find the entire passage in Chapter 5 of Absalom, Absalom, and references in other works as well.  Take it or leave it as a possible source for consideration:"...; I gestate and complete, not aged, just overdue because of some caesarean lack, some cold head-nuzzling forceps of the savage time which should have torn me free, I waited not for light but for the doom which we call female victory which is:  endure and then endure, without rhyme or reason or hope of reward -- and then endure:  I like that blind subterranean fish, that insulated spark whose origin the fish no longer remembers, which pulses and beats at its crepuscular and lethargic tenement with the old unsleeping itch which has no words to speak with other than 'This was called light,'...  no summer's caesarean lack which should have torn me, dead flesh and even embryo, from the living..."  Much of the sentences' missing parts is inappropriate for quotation here since their beauty is ugly.  If you find this irrelevant, remember I didn't write it, I have read it in the other novel over many years.  Faulkner in my opinion is not one book to be read one time, it's all Faulkner books, like Proust continuous and circumambient (to borrow a Faulkner word.)  The objection, should one think, that Vardaman is a child, can be considered before adopting the knee-jerk dismissal of the passage.It is important I think that Miss Rosa is with Quentin Compson who is our "drowning man," our Fisher King, at the moment she is either speaking or thinking this (since speech and internal monologue are worth consideration;) and of course the Quentins are best known from The Sound and the Fury, not the only way these three novels connect. Quentins?  There are the Quentin and Quentin not Quentin to keep in mind as well.

The language of this book is beautiful. Sometimes it was so poetic I had to read a sentence over again just for how the words felt. Sometimes it described a universal feeling I had never seen put into words so perfectly before. Sometimes it was so strongly a dialect that it made my grammar-brain twitch, but even then I enjoyed how it was not the mere semblance of dialect which is so frequently used. The book is told in many different voices, too many to count (though I’m sure someone has). Yet each voice is unique, not only in language but in tone and understanding as well. I was very impressed by this.That said, the story is somewhat disappointing. The wife/mother of the Budren family has died and she wanted to be buried in her hometown, so the family sets out in a mule-drawn wagon carrying her coffin. It has been and is raining heavily, all the bridges are out, and the story follows the family as they find ways around the difficulties they encounter on the road. However, the voices, and when the switches between them are placed, are used to obscure the reality of the action. Most of the reader’s time is spent figuring out what is going on and who each character really is. None of the characters develop in the course of the story; what they are and have always been is merely slowly revealed to the reader. Things happen to them, but the purpose of each event is not to change them but to show who they have always been. This static state frustrated me.I enjoyed the language of the story and the voices very much, but that is as deep as the book went. I rate this book 5/10.

I give “The Sound and the Fury” by Faulkner 3 stars.  Each of the four stories are good and rate at least 4 stars alone.  Due to the different writing styles, mixing times periods for the different sections and not including a simple table of contents makes the book as a whole come off as something just thrown together to publish.  Not a polished work and therefor only 3 stars at best.

I heard about this book for a few years, basically because people said that Faulkner was a racist due to the use of N word in his books, especially this one. But if Toni Morrison finds Faulkner a great writer then I felt I should give him a try. I did research first and learned his writing reflected his time or the time era of his stories. This is when I decided to give this book a shot and glad I did. The N word is in the book but not in a derogatory way I was expecting from what I read. Enough about that.The characters are well written as well as the story or he wouldn't be the great writer he is. Faulkner makes you feel like you are there with the characters and in that time. As you read you will forget the year you are in, that's how much he draws you in to his characters and their stories.Excellent read and a must read for everyone.

summary:
One of William Faulkner’s most admired and accessible novels, Light in August reveals the great American author at the height of his powers. Lena Grove’s resolute search for the father of her unborn child begets a rich, poignant, and ultimately hopeful story of perseverance in the face of mortality. 

It also acquaints us with several of Faulkner’s most unforgettable characters, including the Reverend Gail Hightower, plagued by visions of Confederate horsemen, and Joe Christmas, a ragged, itinerant soul obsessed with his mixed-race ancestry. Powerfully entwining these characters’ stories, Light in August brings to life Faulkner’s imaginary South, one of literature’s great invented landscapes, in all of its unerringly fascinating glory - Yoknapatawpha County.

Along with a new Foreword by C. E. Morgan, this edition reproduces the corrected text of Light in August as established in 1985 by Faulkner expert Noel Polk.
